docs.title: GitHub Markdown
docs.text:
Welcome to the GitHub Markdown site!

The purpose of this page is to list all features regarding the usage of Markdown in GitHub. From basic formatting such as bold and italic to special ones that are part of GitHub Flavourited Markdown (GFM) does this page cover pretty much everything.

docs.title: Usage of Markdown
docs.text:
Markdown can be used on multiple places, including but not limited to:

  • Markdown files (i.e. README.md)
  • Issues, Pull requests, Discussions, Commit Comments and Releases
  • Wiki Pages

docs.title: Pages
docs.text: Since not all features are used everywhere is the site split up into different categories to cover them as good as possible.

docs.title: General
docs.text:
Main Markdown formatting that can be used across GitHub.

Go to Page

docs.title: Issues,  Pull requests and  Discussions
docs.text:
Unique formatting options that can only be used in Issues, Pull requests and Discussions. This may also include Comments on Commits and Releases but was not tested.

Go to Page

docs.title: Wiki
docs.text:
Unique formatting options that can only be used in Wikis.

Go to Page

docs.title: Note about this site and styling
docs.text: This page uses MkDocs together with the PyMdown extensions and various CSS changes. PyMdown extensions provides certain features that help us to emulate some of GitHub's features like task lists. That said is the style often not the same so it may look different to what GitHub offers. We try to copy the overall feel as closely as possible but cannot guarantee it.

docs.title: General
docs.text: This page lists all features that can be used across all places on GitHub, which support markdown formatting.

docs.title: Table of Contents
docs.text:
• Headers
  • Text formatting
    • Italic
    • Bold
    • Strikethrough
    • Combinations
    • Quotes
      • Special Quote blocks
    • Horizontal rule
    • Line breaks
    • Footnotes
  • Lists
    • Ordered
    • Unordered
    • Task Lists
      • Unique behaviour of Task Lists
      • Note about mixed lists
  • Links
    • Normal
    • Reference
    • Image
  • Code
    • Inline code
    • Code Block
      • Syntax highlighting
  • Tables
  • Emojis
  • Math expressions

docs.title: HeadersH2 HeaderAlt H2 Header
docs.text:
Headers are larger text like shown above and also allow you to link to it, when used in Markdown files or the Wiki.

Example

MarkdownResult 
# H1 Header
## H2 Header
### H3 Header
#### H4 Header
##### H5 Header
###### H6 Header

----
Alternative Headers (H1 and H2 only)

Alt H1 Header
======

Alt H2 Header
------

H1 Header H3 Header H4 Header H5 Header H6 Header

Alternative Headers (H1 and H2 only)

Alt H1 Header

docs.title: Text formatting
docs.text: GitHub offers normal Markdown formatting but also adds some own styling.

docs.title: Italic
docs.text:
You can display a text in italic by surrounding it either with a single asterisks (*) or underscore (_).

Example

MarkdownResult 
You can use *asterisks* to make text *italic*.

Alternatively can you also use _underscores_.

You can use asterisks to make text italic.

Alternatively can you also use underscores

docs.title: Bold
docs.text:
Using two Asterisks (*) or two underscores (_) before and after the text makes it bold.

Example

MarkdownResult 
You can use **two asterisks** to make text **bold**.

Alternatively can you also use __two underscores__.

You can use two asterisks to make text bold.

Alternatively can you also use two underscores.

docs.title: Strikethrough
docs.text:
This is a GitHub exclusive formatting code, where you use two tilde (~) before and after text to make it strikethrough.

Example

MarkdownResult 
Don't like this text? Just ~~cross it out!~~

Don't like this text? Just cross it out!

docs.title: Combinations
docs.text:
You can combine the above formatting options to have more special text.

Example

MarkdownResult 
<!-- Note that you have to use underscores when already using asterisks -->
Here is some *italic text with __additional bold__*

Or how about ~~strikethrough with *italic*?~~

Here is some italic text with additional bold

Or how about strikethrough with italic?

docs.title: Quotes
docs.text:
Starting a line with a > followed by a space makes it possible for you to quote a message. The message will have a little bar on the left side and slightly different styling. All types of markdown formatting are supported including quotes in quotes!

Note that you need an empty line between a quote and any normal text below it to not include it in the quote.

Example

MarkdownResult 
Albert Einstein once said:  
> Once you stop learning you start dying.

Albert Einstein once said:

Once you stop learning you start dying.

docs.title: Special Quote blocks
docs.text:
GitHub added a feature where if a quote block starts with either [!NOTE], [!WARNING] or [!IMPORTANT], it will be rendered differently. In addition will the rendered block be a div and not a quoteblock, while the text will also be default white

Important!

  • The first line needs to be > followed by [!NOTE], [!WARNING] or [!IMPORTANT]. Any text to display needs to be on a new line using the quote-pattern.
  • This feature is currently not available in the wiki.

MkDocs Extensions

  • Python Markdown's Admonition (Uses custom CSS)

Example

MarkdownResult 
>  [!NOTE]\
> Drink water to stay hydrated!

----

> [!WARNING]\
> Not drinking water regularely is unhealthy!

----

> [!IMPORTANT]\
> Dirty water is not healthy either.

Note

Drink water to stay hydrated!

Warning

Not drinking water regularely is unhealthy!

Important

Dirty water is not healthy either.

docs.title: Horizontal rule
docs.text:
Using three or more hyphens (-), astersisks (*) or underscores (_) will create a horizontal rule (line) which goes accross the entire text area.

Example

MarkdownResult 
Use three or more hyphens, asterisks or underscores to make a line

---
But make sure there is no text directly above them or it will be converted to a H2 Header!

Use three or more hyphens, asterisks or underscores to make a line

But make sure there is no text directly above them or it will be converted to a H2 Header!

docs.title: Line breaks
docs.text:
To indicate a line break, end a line with two spaces (indicated below using ◦), a backslash (\) or a <br> html tag.

Note

Issues and Pull requests don't require two spaces at the end for line breaks.

Example

MarkdownResult 
We make line breaks, by ending a line with two spaces.◦◦
This line will show below the other.

For a new paragraph, leave an empty line in between.

We make line breaks, by ending a line with two spaces. This line will show below the other.

For a new paragraph, leave an empty line in between.

docs.title: Footnotes
docs.text:
The footnote syntax allows you to link text or URLs without destroying the text's look and formatting. To use a footnote, simply use [^n] - where n is a number or text to use - in the place you want a footnote to be placed and use [^n]: <text> to make a link.

The generated footnotes will link to each other.

MkDocs Extensions

  • Python Markdown's Footnotes extension

Example

MarkdownResult 
Markdown[^1] is a lightweight markup language[^markup] used for creating formatted text.  
It also allows usage of HTML[^html] in it.

[^1]: https://daringfireball.net/projects/markdown/syntax
[^markup]: In computer text processing, a markup language is a system for annotating a document in a way that is visually distinguishable from the content.
  Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Markup_language

<!-- This is a different syntax you can use for multi-line text -->
[^html]:
    Hypertext Markup Language.  
    Made by the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C).

Markdown1 is a lightweight markup language2 used for creating formatted text. It also allows usage of HTML3 in it.

docs.title: Lists
docs.text: You can have various types of lists to order things.

docs.title: Ordered
docs.text:
Starting a line with any number followed by a dot, space and text makes a new Ordered list.

Example

MarkdownResult 
1. This is the first entry.
2. This is the second one.
4. The numbers don't even have to make sense!

----

1. To indent an entry...
   1. ...add 3 spaces before it.
  1. This is the first entry.
  2. This is the second one.
  3. The numbers don't even have to make sense!
  1. To indent an entry...
    1. ...add 3 spaces before it.

docs.title: Unordered
docs.text:
The unordered list has the same behaviour as the ordered list, with the difference that it doesn't use a number and dot, but instead either an asterisks (*) or a hyphen/dash (-)

Example

MarkdownResult 
- This list
- doesn't use numbers.

----

* Because it is
* unordered.

----

- Unordered Lists...
  - ...only require 2 spaces for an indent.
  • This list
  • doesn't use numbers.
  • Because it is
  • unordered.
  • Unordered Lists...
    • ...only require 2 spaces for an indent.

docs.title: Task Lists
docs.text:
Adding a [ ] after a hyphon or asterisks followed by text will create a task list item. This task list item is "unchecked" (Shows an empty box) but can be "checked" by using [x] instead.

MkDocs Extensions

  • PyMdownX's tasklist extension (Uses custom CSS)

Example

MarkdownResult 
Things to do:

- [x] Buy milk
- [x] Make laundry
- [ ] Take over the world

Things to do:

  • Buy milk
  • Make laundry
  • Take over the world

docs.title: Unique behaviour of Task Lists
docs.text: Task lists may show the issues icon () on the right-hand side if hovered over and when used in an issue or Pull request. Clicking this icon will allow to open a new issue that links to this entry.

docs.title: Note about mixed lists
docs.text: You can mix the different list types, but keep in mind that you will need to use 3 or 4 spaces to indent a List of a different type.

docs.title: Links
docs.text: You can link to stuff in various ways

docs.title: Normal
docs.text:
Linking to a page normally is simple. Either post the link directly, or use [text](link)

Example

MarkdownResult 
You can link to sites by posting the URL: https://github.com

Or you link to it as an [embedded link](https://github.com).  
You can even give it [a title](https://github.com 'Go to GitHub!') to show on Hover!

You can link to sites by posting the URL: https://github.com

Or you link to it as an embedded link. You can even give it a title to show on Hover!

docs.title: Reference
docs.text:
Reference URLs are similar to normal ones, with the difference, that you only enclose the text in square brackets and it becomes a embedded link (when text matches). You can use the same reference link at multiple places and use [text][reference link text] in case the text would be different than the reference link's text.

Example

MarkdownResult 
[Link]: https://google.com
[GitHub]: https://github.com

[Reference links][Link] can be used like that to link to sites like [GitHub]!

Reference links can be used like that to link to sites like GitHub!

docs.title: Image
docs.text:
Images can be added the same way as links (including reference link-style), but have an exclamation mark (!) before them.

Example

MarkdownResult 
[github_logo]: https://andre601.ch/GitHub-Markdown/assets/img/github.png

![name][github_logo]  
![github_text](https://andre601.ch/GitHub-Markdown/assets/img/github-text.png)

docs.title: Code
docs.text: GitHub supports inline code and code blocks with syntax highlighting.

docs.title: Inline code
docs.text:
To make inline code, surround the the text with a single backtick (`).

Pro-tip

If you want to display backticks within inline code will you need to start and end the text with 2 backticks.

Example

MarkdownResult 
This is text with some `inline code`.

This is text with some inline code.

docs.title: Code Block
docs.text:
Code blocks allow to display multi-line code and even have syntax highlighting. To put text into a code block, surround it with three backticks (```).

Pro-tip

If you want to display three backticks within code blocks will you need to start and end the text with 4 backticks.

Example

MarkdownResult 
This is some code block stuff  
```
hello world
```

This is some code block stuff 

hello world

docs.title: Syntax highlighting
docs.text:
GitHub provides syntax highlighting support which means that the content within a codeblock can be colorized, depending on what coding language was selected.

Note

GitHub supports Diagrams from Mermaid.js. To display a graph, use mermaid as the syntax highlighting and create the format you would use in Mermaid.js itself.

Example

MarkdownResult 
This here is some JSON with syntax highlighting:  
```json
{
  "hello": "world",
  "how": [
    "are",
    "you?"
  ]
}
```

This here is some JSON with syntax highlighting: 

{
  "hello": "world",
  "how": [
    "are",
    "you?"
  ]
}

docs.title: Tables
docs.text:
Making tables in Markdown is fairly simple.

Example

MarkdownResult 
| Example      | One             |
| ------------ | --------------- |
| You can make | it look pretty! |

Example | Two
--- | ---
Not so pretty... | Yet it still works.

----
Text alignment.

| Title 1 | Title 2                | Title 3   | Title 4       |
| ------- |:---------------------- |:---------:| -------------:|
| default | Left (Same as default) | Centered  | Right         |
Example One You can make it look pretty! Example Two Not so pretty... Yet it still works.

Text alignment.

Title 1 Title 2 Title 3 Title 4 default Left (Same as default) Centered Right

docs.title: Emojis
docs.text:
GitHub allows to render emojis. A emoji is defined using a starting colon (:) followed by any alphanummerical text, hyphens (-) and underscores (_) amd ends with anothor colon.

All available Emojis can be found on ikatyang/emoji-cheat-sheet

MkDocs Extensions

  • PyMdownX's Emoji Extension

Example

MarkdownResult 
Valid emoji:  
:smile:

Invalid emoji:
:some emoji:

Valid emoji:

Invalid emoji: :some emoji:

docs.title: Math expressions
docs.text:
GitHub supports the LaTeX format to display complex math expressions using normal text. To display an expression, surround the expression with either one or two dollar symbols ($) to indicate the start and end of an expression and render it inline or as separate block respectively.

MkDocs Extensions

  • PyMdownX's Arithmatex Extension

Example

MarkdownResult 
Inline math: $\sqrt{3x-1}+(1+x)^2$


Cauchy-Schwarz Inequality:

$$\left( \sum_{k=1}^n a_k b_k \right)^2 \leq \left( \sum_{k=1}^n a_k^2 \right) \left( \sum_{k=1}^n b_k^2 \right)$$

Inline math: \(\sqrt{3x-1}+(1+x)^2\)

Cauchy-Schwarz Inequality:

\[\left( \sum_{k=1}^n a_k b_k \right)^2 \leq \left( \sum_{k=1}^n a_k^2 \right) \left( \sum_{k=1}^n b_k^2 \right)\]

  1. https://daringfireball.net/projects/markdown/syntax ↩

  2. In computer text processing, a markup language is a system for annotating a document in a way that is visually distinguishable from the content. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Markup_language ↩

  3. Hypertext Markup Language. Made by the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C). ↩

docs.title: Issues,  Pull Requests and  Discussions
docs.text:
This page lists all features that can be used across all issues, Pull requests and Discussions on GitHub.

General Features

General features are supported.

docs.title: Table of Contents
docs.text:
• Link shortening
    • Commits
    • Issues and Pull requests
  • File previews
  • Color preview
  • Advanced (task) lists

docs.title: Link shortening
docs.text:
GitHub automatically shortens/alters a list of specific URL-patterns to have it more easy to read.

MkDocs Extensions

  • PyMdownX's MagicLink extension (Applies to all URLs in these docs)

docs.title: Commits
docs.text:
Posting a commit URL will automatically shorten it depending on some conditions. When the URL points to a commit in the same repo, will it be changed to the first 7 characters of the commit SHA. However, when the URL points to a commit of a separate repository, will the resulting text be in the form of user/repo@ commit

Example

Pro-tip

You can also just provide the commit SHA in one of the following formats to link it:

  • :commit For commits within the same repository
  • :user@:commit For commits of User :user
  • :user/:reopo@:commit For commits of User :user in repo :repo
MarkdownResult 
Same repository:

- https://github.com/Andre601/GitHub-Markdown/commit/97c92e943f888101026473b2168c90398d92655c
- 97c92e943f888101026473b2168c90398d92655c

Different repository:

- https://github.com/jlord/sheetsee.js/commit/a5c3785ed8d6a35868bc169f07e40e889087fd2e
- jlord/sheetsee.js@a5c3785ed8d6a35868bc169f07e40e889087fd2e

Same repository:

  • 97c92e
  • 97c92e

Different repository:

  • jlord/sheetsee.js@a5c3785
  • jlord/sheetsee.js@a5c3785

docs.title: Issues and Pull requests
docs.text:
You can link to issues and Pull requests in various ways.

Example

MarkdownResult 
Full URL:

- https://github.com/Andre601/GitHub-Markdown/pull/2
- https://github.com/jlord/sheetsee.js/issues/26

Issue/Pull request number (Own repository):

- #2

Issue/Pull request number (External repository):

- jlord/sheetsee.js#26  
- github/linguist#4039

Full URL:

  • #2
  • jlord/sheetsee.js#26

Issue/Pull request number (Own repository):

  • #2

Issue/Pull request number (External repository):

  • jlord/sheetsee.js#26
  • github/linguist#4039

docs.title: File previews
docs.text:
When you link to a section of a file in a specific commit will GitHub show the targeted content in the Issue/Pull request.

Example

MarkdownResult 
https://github.com/Andre601/GitHub-Markdown/blob/97c92e943f888101026473b2168c90398d92655c/requirements.txt#L1
GitHub-Markdown/requirements.txtLine 1 in 97c92e9 
1 | mkdocs-material>=5.0.0

docs.title: Color preview
docs.text:
When using inline code can you use a hashtag, followed by a hexadecimal color value (i.e. #ffffff) and GitHub will automatically add a small square in the provided color to it.

Example

MarkdownResult 
I like green: `#16c60c`

I like green: #16c60c 🟩

docs.title: Advanced (task) lists
docs.text:
Whenever you link an issue, Pull request or Discussion in a list or Task list will GitHub automatically display the title, id and the current state of the issue, Pull request or Discussion. Whenever a issue or Pull request is linked in a task list and said issue/Pull request is closed or merged will the corresponding task list entry get "checked".

MkDocs Extensions

  • PyMdownX's tasklist extension (Uses custom CSS)
  • PyMdownX's Emoji Extension (Uses Material for MkDocs' icon sets)

Example

MarkdownResult 
Representation not 100% accurate

- [ ] #15
- #16

External repository:

- https://github.com/github/feedback/discussions/4251

Representation not 100% accurate

  • Replace info with example admonition #15
  • Test linked PR #16

External repository:

  • The new Task List (Beta) community/community#4251

docs.title: Wiki
docs.text:
This page lists all features that can be used inside Wikis on GitHub repositories.

General Features

General features are supported.

docs.title: Table of Contents
docs.text: • Wiki Page links

docs.title: Wiki Page links
docs.text:
The Wiki pages have a unique Link patternt that can be used to link to other pages on the Wiki (optionally with a separate text to display). Any other link type is also supported.

You can easly link to other pages by starting a link with two opening square brackets ([) followed by the page name and closing it with two closing square brackets (]).

Example

MarkdownResult 
[[general]]  
[[issues-pull-requests-and-discussions]]

Displaying an alternative text:  
[[Main Formatting|general]]  
[[Issues, Pull requests and Discussions formatting|issues-pull-requests-and-discussions]]

Link to a specific section in a page:  
[[Reference Links|general#reference]]

general issues-pull-requests-and-discussions

Displaying an alternative text: Main Formatting Issues, Pull requests and Discussions formatting

Link to a specific section in a page: Reference Links
